body: Do you see the issue with 8.14.1 stable as well?

> Do you see the issue with 8.14.1 stable as well?

Yes, I see the same behavior when testing from the [curl-8_14_1](https://github.com/curl/curl/releases/tag/curl-8_14_1) tag.

This patch appears to fix the error:
```patch
diff --git a/lib/vtls/schannel.c b/lib/vtls/schannel.c
index bea8eef8c..c8bd2a07b 100644
--- a/lib/vtls/schannel.c
+++ b/lib/vtls/schannel.c
@@ -665,8 +665,7 @@ schannel_acquire_credential_handle(struct Curl_cfilter *cf,
           pszPassword[0] = 0;
 
         if(Curl_isVistaOrGreater)
-          cert_store = PFXImportCertStore(&datablob, pszPassword,
-                                          PKCS12_NO_PERSIST_KEY);
+          cert_store = PFXImportCertStore(&datablob, pszPassword, 0);
         else
           cert_store = PFXImportCertStore(&datablob, pszPassword, 0);
```

I suspect `PKCS12_NO_PERSIST_KEY` is interfering with the TLS handshake. Quoting https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/api/wincrypt/nf-wincrypt-pfximportcertstore:

> PKCS12_NO_PERSIST_KEY
> This typically applies during a TLS handshake: if the handshake is performed externally to the calling process in LSASS.exe, it is not possible to use PKCS12_NO_PERSIST_KEY when moving from the calling process to LSASS

I expect removing `PKCS12_NO_PERSIST_KEY` is not desirable. https://github.com/curl/curl/issues/9300 suggests `PKCS12_NO_PERSIST_KEY` was added to avoid persisting files. With this patch, I see files created and persisted in `C:\Users\Administrator\AppData\Roaming\Microsoft\Crypto\RSA\S-1-5-21-238269189-1184923242-2057656851-500`.
I have no clue what to do with this. Suggestions?

It seems no one wants to work on this. It seems we don't even know what the correct fix should be.

I'm proposing we document this as a known bug. Unfortunate, but I see no alternative.

I have been poking at this in the background. Experiments and references suggest persisting keys is required to support TLS 1.3:

Quoting [.NET runtime](https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/blob/main/src/libraries/System.Net.Security/src/System/Net/Security/SslStreamPal.Windows.cs#L261-L262):
> on Windows we do not support ephemeral keys.

Quoting [Private Key Lifetime on Windows and the January 2021 .NET Framework Security and Quality Rollup](https://support.microsoft.com/en-us/topic/private-key-lifetime-on-windows-and-the-january-2021-net-framework-security-and-quality-rollup-3f097a10-f798-4ffd-8511-4757ebaf2c70):
> The default behavior is that the private key gets loaded into a persisted (named) key via one of the system cryptography libraries

Quoting https://stackoverflow.com/a/72101855:
> The TLS layer on Windows requires that the private key be written to disk

Quoting [PFXImportCertStore](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/api/wincrypt/nf-wincrypt-pfximportcertstore):
> if the handshake is performed externally to the calling process in LSASS.exe, it is not possible to use PKCS12_NO_PERSIST_KEY

A possible solution may be to temporarily import a persisted key and later delete. I do not-yet know exactly when is safe to delete the imported key (possibly `schannel_session_free`?). But I expect I can provide some fix eventually.

issue.title: KNOWN_BUGS: Access violation sending client cert with SChannel

It seems we can select between crashing or leaking sensitive files because Schannel is buggy.

Closes #17626

issue.body:
# Summary

Import Secure Channel keys as persisted and delete later. Fixes access violation reported in #17626.

# Background & Motivation

Experiments and references suggest persisted keys (rather than ephemeral) are required to support TLS 1.3.

Quoting [.NET runtime](https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/blob/main/src/libraries/System.Net.Security/src/System/Net/Security/SslStreamPal.Windows.cs#L261-L262):
> on Windows we do not support ephemeral keys.

Quoting [Private Key Lifetime on Windows and the January 2021 .NET Framework Security and Quality Rollup](https://support.microsoft.com/en-us/topic/private-key-lifetime-on-windows-and-the-january-2021-net-framework-security-and-quality-rollup-3f097a10-f798-4ffd-8511-4757ebaf2c70):
> The default behavior is that the private key gets loaded into a persisted (named) key via one of the system cryptography libraries

Quoting https://stackoverflow.com/a/72101855:
> The TLS layer on Windows requires that the private key be written to disk

Quoting [PFXImportCertStore](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/api/wincrypt/nf-wincrypt-pfximportcertstore):
> if the handshake is performed externally to the calling process in LSASS.exe, it is not possible to use PKCS12_NO_PERSIST_KEY

This PR models the .NET runtime [SafeCertContextHandleWithKeyContainerDeletion](https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/blob/0d628dae1cb5b8d0eb76d9549134edfe30d6219c/src/libraries/Common/src/Microsoft/Win32/SafeHandles/SafeCertContextHandleWithKeyContainerDeletion.cs) to delete the persisted key.

# Testing

This PR adds a regression test. `PFXImportCertStore` may import as a CAPI key or CNG key. On my machine, the test imported as CAPI. To also test CNG key deletion, the test was run by temporarily passing the [flag `PKCS12_PREFER_CNG_KSP`](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/api/wincrypt/nf-wincrypt-pfximportcertstore) to trigger storing in CNG.

# Caveats

`ncrypt.dll` is newly required for CNG key deletion.

`delete_imported_key` ignores errors.

If the process terminates abnormally, the key may remain on disk.
